Introduction to Networking.title: Introduction to Computer Networking
Introduction to Networking.description: This chapter introduces the basics of computer networks, types of networks, communication models, and key concepts required to understand data transmission.

details: A computer network is a collection of interconnected devices that communicate and share resources.
Provides communication, file sharing, remote access, and data transfer.
Star — central hub connects all nodes.
Mesh — every device connects to every device.
Half-duplex — both directions but not simultaneously (e.g., walkie-talkie).
Full-duplex — both directions simultaneously (e.g., phone call).

sections.summary: Networking allows devices to communicate, share data, and connect globally using structured transmission methods.

OSI Model.title: OSI Model
OSI Model.description: This chapter explains the OSI reference model, a seven-layer architecture used to standardize network communication.

details: Each layer has a specific function and interacts with adjacent layers.
Data Link — frames, MAC addressing, error detection.
Application — user-facing protocols like HTTP, FTP.

sections.summary: The OSI model organizes digital communication into structured, logical layers that improve interoperability and understanding.

TCP/IP Architecture.title: TCP/IP Architecture
TCP/IP Architecture.description: This chapter covers the 4-layer TCP/IP model used by modern internet communication.

details: Network Interface — physical network hardware and drivers.
Transport Layer — TCP, UDP for communication.
Used by routers to forward data.
TCP ensures reliability using handshake and acknowledgements.
Together form a reliable communication system.

sections.summary: TCP/IP model powers the modern internet and simplifies data communication into four major layers.

IP Addressing & Subnetting.title: IP Addressing & Subnetting
IP Addressing & Subnetting.description: This chapter explains IP addressing, IPv4 vs IPv6, subnetting, and network mask calculations.

details: Includes public and private IP ranges.
Dividing a larger network into smaller networks.
Subnet mask determines network and host parts.
Reduces IP wastage and improves routing efficiency.

sections.summary: IP addressing and subnetting structure networks efficiently and enable proper routing across networks.

Routing Algorithms.title: Routing Algorithms
Routing Algorithms.description: This chapter explains how routers determine the best path for data packets.

details: Routing selects optimal paths for data packets.
Static routing: manually configured, no auto-update.
Dynamic routing: updates automatically using algorithms.

sections.summary: Routing algorithms help routers efficiently forward packets and maintain network stability.

Transport Layer: TCP vs UDP.title: Transport Layer — TCP vs UDP
Transport Layer: TCP vs UDP.description: This chapter compares TCP and UDP, explaining reliability, speed, and use cases.

details: Applications: web browsing, email, file transfer.
TCP = reliable, slower | UDP = fast, unreliable.
TCP performs congestion control; UDP does not.

sections.summary: The transport layer manages application communication by choosing between reliability (TCP) and speed (UDP).

Application Layer Protocols.title: Application Layer Protocols
Application Layer Protocols.description: This chapter explains user-facing protocols that enable communication over the internet.

details: Converts domain names to IP addresses.
File Transfer Protocol for sending/receiving files.
SFTP adds encryption for secure transfer.

sections.summary: Application layer protocols power essential services like browsing, file transfer, and email communication.

Network Security.title: Network Security
Network Security.description: This chapter explains threats, attacks, firewalls, encryption, and secure communication practices.

details: Protect internal networks from external threats.

sections.summary: Network security protects systems, communication, and data from unauthorized access and attacks.
